span.a: You are currently on this page - Coronavirus Update

span.strong: Schools Closed for Duration of Public Health Emergency

p.span: Gov. Tony Evers on March 13, 2020 ordered the closure of all K-12 Wisconsin schools, public and private, from Wednesday, March 18 to April 5, as part of the state's efforts to respond to and contain the spread of COVID-19 in Wisconsin. The announcement affects almost 855,000 students in more than 400 districts across the state - and adds Wisconsin to a growing list of states to close schools.

“Closing our schools is not a decision I made lightly, but keeping our kids, our educators, our families, and our communities safe is a top priority as we continue our work to respond to and prevent further spread of COVID-19 in Wisconsin,” Evers said. “Kids and families across Wisconsin often depend on our schools to access food and care. We are going to continue working to do everything we can to ensure kids and families have the resources and support they need while schools are closed.”

On Sunday, March 15th, McFarland School district issued the following statement: In the best interests of the health of our students, staff, and families, all Dane County Public Schools, including McFarland School District, have decided to close effective immediately. This closure will extend minimally through Sunday, April 5. This closure applies to all student instruction, extra-curricular activities, and outside groups.

strong.span: On Tuesday, March 17, Governor Evers extended the state school closures "for the duration of the public health emergency (

span.span: full order can be seen here

td.p: On April 16, Governor Evers extended the Safer-At-Home order until May 26, 2020 including ordering K-12 schools to remain closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 (full order can be seen here).

p.span: - see right side-bar

Informal distance learning resources will be available no earlier than Monday March 23. If you are task-oriented and have a hard time sitting still, learning how to use Zoom for virtual meetings can be a productive use of time (and it’s fun!). We’re putting easy-to-use materials together for folks who want to check it out. Please do NOT reach out to teachers to provide assignments at this time. It’s “Time-out” on formal learning for the moment.

strong.span: Home Internet Access (Spectrum, TDS, and Four Lakes Broadband

p.span:
March 27, 2020
Dear McFarland Students and Families,
I have a few updates for you as we move into spring break. The first section of this message has new information about what you can expect beginning April 6, followed by a few reminders from earlier in the week.
New information
Thank you very much for your responses to our Distance Learning Feedback Survey. We heard from nearly 200 students and parents yesterday, and you gave us some really valuable feedback that is helping us plan for April 6 and beyond. There are a couple of topics that came up in the survey that I want to address.
Learning from a distance
One of the biggest challenges we are facing with distance learning is that every student’s “virtual learning environment” is different. Teachers can’t ensure that all students have the resources and support they need to be successful in the same way that we can when we’re in school together. In all grades, we will do everything we possibly can to help students continue to learn and grow. Like everything else we are living through, it will just look different.

will receive their special education services to the extent possible which will include their accommodations, modifications, specially designed instruction and related services. Specially designed instruction and related services minutes will be scheduled with parents and case managers.
will receive their accommodations to the extent possible in a virtual setting.

span.strong: Student Services (School Counselor, School Psychologist, School Social Worker)

p.span: are available to students and families during office hours and by appointment.

br.span:
Our principals will be sharing more details with you very soon on what you and your child can expect to see with Distance Learning on April 6.
Changes you will notice beginning the week of April 6:

p.span: All students K-12 will begin accessing new learning beginning April 6th.

Teachers K-12 will be marking assignments as Turned In or Missing. K-5 will do this with informal checklists. 6-12 you will see this reflected on Infinite Campus. Teachers will check in with students who are not engaged in the assignments to see what additional supports they can offer.
Timely feedback on learning will be provided at all levels in an age appropriate manner.

br.span: The emphasis during distance learning is on giving formative feedback to students on their learning, not on “ grading” work. That said, we will be completing year-end report cards. When that time comes:

p.span: K-5 reports cards will use a scale of 3/2/Not Assessed at the end of the year
6-12 students will be using Pass/Fail/ Incomplete

span.strong: Technology support for students and families
span.br:
Please visit our new Family/Student Technology Resources page on the District website. This page includes a Tech Support Request Form. Please let us know how we can help you!
Broadband providers have a number of supports available for students and educators during the COVID-19 health crisis. Here are some examples (also listed on our new webpage):

p.span: Spectrum https://www.spectrum.net/support/internet/coronavirus-internet-offer-students/
TDS https://tdstelecom.com/covid-19.html
DPI resources https://dpi.wi.gov/broadband

br.br:
Lessons have about half of the content compared to what students are accustomed to, and with a sharp focus on essential knowledge and skills. This will mean 2 - 5 hours per day of total instruction, depending on grade level.
Each day, students should do 5 things:

p.span: Read for 20-30 minutes
Be physically active
Do something for their social/emotional health
Complete an assignment with a required response of some kind in one of the tested 4 subjects (math, ELA, social studies, science)
Complete and assignment with a required response of some kind in an elective subject

br.span:
The learning experiences that we provide must be accessible to all of our kids. This means we have to think differently, and carefully about how we support students with IEP's and other unique needs, including ELL and advanced learner supports.
Teacher-Student Connections
New learning will be presented in an on-demand format, such as a recorded lesson and/or in print format.
Teachers will be holding office hours to allow students to ask questions if they need help. Each school's staff will organize its office hour schedules. Office hours can happen in any number of formats - Zoom, Google Hangout, email, and we're working on some options for phone calls, too. In addition to office hours, teachers are encouraged to hold Zoom sessions for community-building and/or small group discussions and support.
Attendance: We will not be taking attendance in the same way we do when school is in session in our buildings. Teachers will be monitoring student engagement. If we don't hear from your student, we'll be checking in to make sure everything is ok, and to see what support may be needed.
More information to come:
You will be hearing from your child's principal with more details about Distance Learning 2.0. We will continue to post distance learning resources on the Distance Learning website.
Have a healthy and safe spring break, and I’ll see you on April 6!
Andrew Briddell

p.span: Questions that are not addressed in the above link can be submitted here. Please check the document before submitting new questions.
